qas.question: When should the noise-based speed be used?

answers.text: the noise-based speed (40:1) is higher than the saturation-based speed

qas.question: What is the range for exposure latitude?

answers.text: from the saturation-based speed to the 10:1 noise-based speed

qas.question: What is another speed that can also be reported by the camera?
Why should noise-based speed be rounded down to a lower standard?

answers.text: exposure according to the lower saturation-based speed would not result in a visibly better image
how speed ratings should be reported by the camera

qas.question: A lower saturation-based speed would create a better what?
What is the ratio for the saturation-based speed?
Is the SOS rounded up or down?

plausible_answers.text: using the noise-based speed would lead to overexposed images

qas.question: Why are saturation-based speeds rounded down?

context: The standard specifies <a4_0>how speed ratings should be reported by the camera<a4_0/>. If <a0_0>the noise-based speed (40:1) is higher than the saturation-based speed<a0_0/>, the noise-based speed should be reported, rounded downwards to a standard value (e.g. 200, 250, 320, or 400). The rationale is that <a3_0>exposure according to the lower saturation-based speed would not result in a visibly better <b5_0>image<b5_0/><a3_0/>. In addition, an exposure latitude can be specified, ranging <a1_0>from the saturation-based speed to the <b6_0>10:1<b6_0/> noise-based speed<a1_0/>. If the noise-based speed (40:1) is lower than the saturation-based speed, or undefined because of high noise, the saturation-based speed is specified, rounded <b7_0>upwards<b7_0/> to a standard value, because <b8_0><b9_0>using the noise-based speed<b8_0/> would lead to overexposed images<b9_0/>. The camera may also report the <a2_0>SOS-based speed<a2_0/> (explicitly as being an SOS speed), rounded to the nearest standard speed rating.
